questions.text: A 28 year old woman undergoes an illegal abortion and is rushed to the emergency department after collapsing at home. On arrival, she is unresponsive and later dies. Upon forensic examination, the immediate cause of death is determined. Which of the following is NOT typically considered an immediate cause of death in cases of criminal abortion?
questions.explanation:
Immediate cause

Delayed cause (onset within 48 hrs to 72 hrs)

Remote cause

1) Vagal inhibition

2) Air embolism

3) Hemorrhage

4) Fat embolism

5) Amniotic fluid embolism

6) Rarely poisoning.

1) Septicemia

2) Pyaemia

3) Confined local infection and toxemia

4) General peritonitis

5) Tetanus.

1) Jaundice and renal failure

2) Bacterial endocarditis

3) Pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: Bestiality is a term given to which of the following unnatural sexual offenses?
questions.correct_answer: D. Sexual intercourse with an animal

questions.text: Which of the following acts cannot be considered as rape?

options.label: A
options.text: Inserting an article into the urethra

options.label: B
options.text: Manipulating any part of a woman’s body to cause penetration

questions.explanation:
BNS

BNS 63 (Old: Section 375 IPC)

Definition

Unlawful sexual intercourse by a man with a woman through force or under certain conditions

Acts considered

  • Penetrates his penis into the vagina, mouth, urethra, or anus
  • Inserts any object or body part (not his penis) or applies his mouth to the vagina, mouth, urethra, or anus (Option A ruled out) (Option D ruled out)
  • Manipulates any part of the woman's body to cause penetration into the vagina, urethra, or anus (Option B ruled out)

Circumstances

  • Against her will
  • Without her consent
  • With her consent obtained through fear of death or hurt
  • With her consent, when she believes he is her husband due to impersonation
  • When she cannot understand the nature of consent due to unsoundness of mind, intoxication, or being drugged
  • Statutory rape: With or without her consent, if she is under 18 years of age
  • When she is unable to communicate consent

Exception

  • Medical interventions or procedures
  • Sexual intercourse by a man with his wife if she is not under 18 years of age (Option C)

questions.text: Match the BNS sections with the offences BNS Section Offense 1. 97 a. Importing a girl under 21 years into India from a foreign country for illicit intercourse 2. 137 (1) (b) b. Abducting a minor from lawful guardianship 3. 96 c. Abducting a child under 10 years to take any moveable property 4. 141 d. Procuring a girl under 18 years for illicit intercourse
questions.explanation:
New

Old

About

BNS 97

Section 369 IPC

Kidnapping or abducting a child under 10 years with the intent to take dishonestly any moveable property from the child

BNS 137 (1)(b)

Section 361 IPC

Kidnapping or abducting a minor from lawful guardianship:

  • Boy under 16 years
  • Girl under 18 years

BNS 96

Section 366A IPC

Procuring a girl under 18 years old for illicit intercourse or for prostitution

BNS 141

Section 366B IPC

Importing a girl under 21 years into India from a foreign country for illicit intercourse

questions.text: A man attacks a woman in public and tries to disrobe her. What is the punishment he will get for this?
questions.correct_answer: A. 3-7 years of imprisonment and fine
questions.explanation:
Definition

Unwanted sexual behavior or touching of a female without her consent, intending to outrage her modesty

Legal Aspect
  • BNS 74
  • Old: Section 354 IPC
  • 1-5 years imprisonment and/or fine
  • The offense is cognizable, non-bailable, and non-compoundable
  • Tried by any Magistrate

Whoever assaults or uses criminal force on any woman or abets such act with the intention of disrobing or compelling her to be naked
  • BNS 76
  • Old: Section 354-B IPC
  • 3-7 years imprisonment and fine (Option A)

questions.text: Acid attack comes under which of the following BNS sections?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Throwing or attempting to throw acid or any corrosive substance that can cause bodily injury, disfigurement, scars, temporary or permanent disability, or grievous hurt

BNS sections

Section BNS 124 (1) and Section BNS 124 (2) (Option A)

Punishment

Imprisonment from 5 to 7 or 10 years to life and fine

questions.text: A 32 year old man gets into an argument and intentionally causes severe injuries to another person, resulting in a broken arm and significant physical pain. The police decided to charge him under the appropriate section of the BNS. Which section of the BNS is appropriate in this context?

options.label: A
options.text: He is charged under the section BNS 115 (1)

options.label: B
options.text: He is charged under the section BNS 115 (2)

options.label: C
options.text: He is charged under the section BNS 117 (2)

options.label: D
options.text: He is charged under the section BNS 124 (2)

questions.correct_answer: C. He is charged under the section BNS 117 (2)
questions.explanation:
BNS

Old

Section of IPC

Offense

Punishment (Imprisonment)

Fine

BNS 115 (2)

323

Voluntarily causing simple hurt

Up to 1 year

With/without fine (up to ₹10000)

BNS 118 (1)

324

Voluntarily causing simple hurt by dangerous weapons/means

Up to 3 years

With/without fine (up to ₹20000)

BNS 117 (2)

325

Voluntarily causing grievous hurt

Up to 7 years

Yes

BNS 118 (2)

326

Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons/means

Mandatory minimum imprisonment for one year

Up to 10 years

Yes

BNS 124 (1)

326-A

Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by use of acids

10 years to life imprisonment

Yes (paid to the victim)

BNS 124 (2)

326-B

Voluntarily throwing or attempting to throw acid

5-7 years

Yes

BNS 120 (2)

331

Voluntarily causing grievous hurt to extort confession, or to compel restoration of property

Up to 10 years

Yes

questions.text: A 35 year old man was assaulted, leading to several injuries and is hospitalized. You are tasked with determining whether the case fits the legal classification of grievous hurt under BNS 116 for some of the expected events. Which of the following scenarios would NOT be classified as grievous hurt?

options.label: A
options.text: The person dies due to an injury that, under normal circumstances, was not intended to cause death.

options.label: B
options.text: The person suffers an abdominal injury causing the intestines to protrude and is hospitalized for 22 days.

options.label: C
options.text: The person sustains a deep injury without any fracture or permanent disfigurement.

options.label: D
options.text: The person is in a coma for 20 days following a severe head injury.

questions.correct_answer: A. The person dies due to an injury that, under normal circumstances, was not intended to cause death.

questions.text: A 40 year old man was involved in an altercation and sustained multiple injuries. You are evaluating whether these injuries qualify as grievous hurt under BNS 116. Which of the following scenarios does NOT meet the criteria for classifying the injury as grievous hurt?

options.label: A
options.text: He is rendered impotent after sustaining a serious genital injury.

options.label: B
options.text: He loses a single tooth due to a punch on his face

options.label: C
options.text: He attains a cut injury on his face that temporarily alters his appearance.

options.label: D
options.text: He got his wrist fractured due to a heavy fall

questions.correct_answer: C. He attains a cut injury on his face that temporarily alters his appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly defines the term "injury" as per legal terminology?

options.label: A
options.text: Harm caused to a person’s reputation, body, or property, irrespective of legality.

options.label: B
options.text: Any harm legally or illegally caused to a person's mind, body, or property.

options.label: C
options.text: Any harm caused to a person's physical body.

options.label: D
options.text: Any harm illegally caused to a person, in body, mind, reputation, or property.

questions.correct_answer: D. Any harm illegally caused to a person, in body, mind, reputation, or property.
questions.explanation:
IPC

Term

BNS

Definition

44

Injury

Sec 2(14)

The word "injury" denotes any harm illegally caused to any person, in body, mind, reputation, or property. (Option D)

45

Life

Sec 2(17)

The word "life" denotes the life of a human being, unless the contrary appears from the context.

46

Death

Sec 2(6)

The word "death" denotes the death of a human being, unless the contrary appears from the context.

questions.text: A 11-year old child accused of murder was let go free after the trial. What could be the likely explanation in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: BNS 20 - depending on the mental maturity

options.label: C
options.text: BNS 21 - depending on the mental maturity

questions.correct_answer: C. BNS 21 - depending on the mental maturity

questions.text: Match the BNS sections with the offense BNS Section Offense 1. 104 a. Attempt to commit suicide. 2. 107 b. Punishment for murder by life convict. 3. 109 c. Abetment of suicide of child or insane person. 4. 226 d. Attempt to murder.
questions.explanation:
BNS Section

Offense

104
  • Punishment for murder by life convict.
  • Punishment: Death penalty

105
  • Punishment for culpable homicide not amounting to murder.

Punishment:

  • Part I: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years and fine.
  • Part II: Up to 10 years imprisonment or fine.

107
  • Abetment of suicide of child or insane person.
  • Punishment: Death penalty or life imprisonment or up to 10 years and fine.

108
  • Abetment of suicide.
  • Punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine.

109
  • Attempt to murder.
  • Punishment: Up to life imprisonment or up to 10 years and fine. If injury occurs, may extend to life imprisonment.

110
  • Attempt to commit culpable homicide.
  • Punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment or fine, or both. If injury occurs, may extend to 7 years.

226
  • Attempt to commit suicide.
  • Punishment: Up to 1 year imprisonment or fine.

questions.text: A 60 year old man gets into a heated argument with his neighbor during a community event. In a fit of rage, he pushes the neighbour hard, causing him to fall and hit his head on a concrete surface. The neighbor sustains a severe head injury and dies a few hours later in the hospital. He did not intend to kill but was reckless during the confrontation. Which section of the BNS would he be most likely be charged under?

A surgeon deliberately administers a lethal dose of anesthesia to a patient during a routine surgery because of a personal grudge. The patient dies on the operating table. Investigations reveal that the surgeon was fully aware that the dose would cause death. Under which section of the BNS would the surgeon be charged?

Match the BNS sections with the offense BNS Section Offense 1.274 a. Adulteration of food or drink intended for sale 2. 275 b. Sale of adulterated drugs 3. 276 c. Sale of noxious food or drink 4. 277 d. Adulteration of drugs
questions.explanation:
BNS Section

Offense

274
  • Adulteration of food or drink intended for sale.
  • Punishment: Imprisonment upto 6 months or fine.
  • Bailable

275
  • Sale of noxious food or drinks.
  • Punishment: Imprisonment upto 6 months or fine.
  • Bailable

276
  • Adulteration of drugs.
  • Punishment: Imprisonment upto 6 months or fine.
  • Non bailable

277
  • Sale of adulterated drugs.
  • Punishment: Imprisonment upto 6 months or fine.
  • Bailable

questions.text: A 32 year old man, unaware that he is HIV positive, has been in a relationship with a woman for the past year. Neither he nor his partner has undergone recent medical check-ups, and they have been engaging in unprotected intercourse. Unfortunately, she tests positive for HIV as well. This act comes under which BNS?
questions.explanation:
Option Section Pertains To Applicability in Case
BNS 271 (Option A) Negligent act likely to spread infection Requires knowledge or reason to believe the act is likely to spread infection. Not applicable – he was unaware.
BNS 272 (Option B ruled out) Adulteration of food/drug Related to tampering with consumables. Not related.
BNS 106A (Option C ruled out) Organised crime/terror-related offences Not related to infectious disease or health violations. Not applicable.
BNS 109 (Option D ruled out) Abetment of an offence Secondary offence when someone aids/instigates a crime. Not primary here.

questions.text: Match the Following (Based on BNS Sections): Code Description 1) BNS 227 a) Giving false evidence under oath 2) BNS 229 b) Punishment for giving false evidence under oath 3) BNS 234 c) Punishment for issuing a false certificate 4) BNS 238 d) Punishment for causing disappearance of vital evidence
questions.explanation:
Section

Description

BNS 227

Giving false evidence under oath (Perjury)

BNS 229

Punishment for giving false evidence under oath (Punishment for perjury)

BNS 234

Punishment for issuing a false certificate

BNS 238

Punishment for disappearance of vital evidence

Section

Offence

Punishment

BNS 227

Giving false evidence/statement under oath by a witness (Perjury)

As defined under law

BNS 228

Fabrication of evidence

As per provisions

BNS 229

Punishment for giving false evidence under oath

Up to 7 years imprisonment + fine

BNS 234

Punishment for issuing a false certificate

Up to 7 years imprisonment + fine

BNS 238

Disappearance of vital evidence

Up to 7 years imprisonment + fine

BNS 239

Intentional omission of vital information by a person legally bound to inform

As per provisions

questions.text: Person presented to ED with complaints of severe chest pain for 1 hour. CT chest done revealed the presence of Aortic dissection. Patient was taken up for an emergency endovascular surgery without obtaining consent as there were no caregivers present at the time of presentation. Patient succumbed to hypotensive shock during the procedure. The surgeon will not be held liable under
questions.explanation:
BNS 25
  • Act not intended to cause death/grievous hurt done by a person >18 years of age after rightful consent.

BNS 26 (Option A)
  • Act done in good faith for a person’s benefit after obtaining lawful consent.

BNS 27 (Option B)
  • Act done in good faith for the benefit of a child (<12 years) or a person with unsound mind with guardian’s consent

BNS 28 (Option C)
  • Consent given by a person under fear or threat/under misconception of fact/child under 12 years of age/person of unsound mind/under intoxicated state is considered invalid.

BNS 30 (Option D)
  • An act done in good faith for the benefit of a person without their consent is not an offense.
  • This is true if the circumstances make it impossible for the person to give consent.
  • Known as Doctrine of Anticipation.

questions.text: BNS 27 deals with

options.label: A
options.text: Act done in good faith for the benefit of a child (<12 years) with guardian’s consent

options.label: B
options.text: Act done in good faith for a person’s benefit after obtaining lawful consent

options.label: C
options.text: Act not intended to cause death/grievous hurt done by a person >18 years of age

options.label: D
options.text: Consent is not valid when it is given by fear/misconception

questions.correct_answer: A. Act done in good faith for the benefit of a child (<12 years) with guardian’s consent
questions.explanation:
BNS 25 (Option C)
  • Any act which causes harm except the act intended to cause death or grievous hurt is not an offense if it is done with the consent of a person who is above 18 years of age.
  • Consent can be either Implied (or) Expressed.
  • E.g., two boxers fighting each other in an olympic match.

BNS 26 (Option B)
  • If a person commits an act done in good faith and with the consent for the benefit of that person, it will not be considered an offense.
  • E.g., a surgeon performing surgery after getting consent.

BNS 27 (Option A)
  • Any act done in good faith for the benefit of a child (<12 years) or a person of unsound mind after obtaining guardian’s (caregiver’s) consent.
  • Neither the Doer nor the Caregiver would be held responsible for any unforeseen consequences.
  • E.g., a doctor doing necessary medical examination on a child (<12years) after obtaining guardian’s consent.

BNS 28 (Option D)
  • Consent is not valid if it is given by a person under fear or threat/under misconception of fact/child under 12 years of age/person of unsound mind/under intoxicated state.
  • E.g., a female giving consent for sex to her boss under fear of losing her job is considered invalid.

questions.text: Husband physically assaults his wife following a verbal altercation between them. On enquiry, it is known that the Husband was under the influence of alcohol during this act and his wife reveals that he is a chronic alcoholic, drinks on a daily basis. Which section deals with the liable act done by her husband?
questions.explanation:
BNS 20 (Option A)

Act done by a child below 7 years of age - NOT held liable

BNS 21

Act done by a child between 7-12 years of age can/cannot be held liable depending on the mental maturity (assessed by The court of law)

BNS 22 (Option B)

Act of a person of unsound mind/insane - NOT held liable (McNaughten’s rule)

BNS 23 (Option C)

Act of a person done under involuntary intoxication - NOT held liable

BNS 24 (Option D)

Act of a person done under voluntary intoxication - Held liable
